definition:
The [*zero polynomial*]{} in a ring $R[X]$ of polynomials over a ring
$R$ is the identity element $\textbf{0}$ of this polynomial ring:
$$f\!+\!\textbf{0} \;=\; \textbf{0}\!+\!f \;=\; f \quad\forall\, f\in R[X]$$
So the zero polynomial is also the absorbing element for the
multiplication of polynomials.

All coefficients of the zero polynomial are equal to 0, i.e.
$$\textbf{0} \;:=\; (0,\,0,\,0,\,...).$$

Because always $$f\cdot\textbf{0} \;=\; \textbf{0}$$ and because in
general $\deg(fg) = \deg(f)+\deg(g)$ when $R$ has no zero divisors, one
may define that that the zero polynomial has no at all, or alternatively
that $$\deg(\textbf{0}) \;=\; -\infty$$ (see the extended real numbers).
